scene.title: SCENE I. Court of Macbeth's castle.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter BANQUO, and FLEANCE bearing a torch before him

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: How goes the night, boy?

speech.speaker: FLEANCE
speech.line: The moon is down; I have not heard the clock.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: And she goes down at twelve.

speech.speaker: FLEANCE
speech.line: I take't, 'tis later, sir.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: Hold, take my sword. There's husbandry in heaven;
Their candles are all out. Take thee that too.
A heavy summons lies like lead upon me,
And yet I would not sleep: merciful powers,
Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature
Gives way to in repose!
speech.stagedir: Enter MACBETH, and a Servant with a torch
speech.line: Give me my sword.
Who's there?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: A friend.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: What, sir, not yet at rest? The king's a-bed:
He hath been in unusual pleasure, and
Sent forth great largess to your offices.
This diamond he greets your wife withal,
By the name of most kind hostess; and shut up
In measureless content.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Being unprepared,
Our will became the servant to defect;
Which else should free have wrought.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: All's well.
I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters:
To you they have show'd some truth.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: I think not of them:
Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve,
We would spend it in some words upon that business,
If you would grant the time.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: At your kind'st leisure.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: If you shall cleave to my consent, when 'tis,
It shall make honour for you.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: So I lose none
In seeking to augment it, but still keep
My bosom franchised and allegiance clear,
I shall be counsell'd.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Good repose the while!

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: Thanks, sir: the like to you!

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready,
She strike upon the bell. Get thee to bed.
Is this a dagger which I see before me,
The handle toward my hand? Come, let me clutch thee.
I have thee not, and yet I see thee still.
Art thou not, fatal vision, sensible
To feeling as to sight? or art thou but
A dagger of the mind, a false creation,
Proceeding from the heat-oppressed brain?
I see thee yet, in form as palpable
As this which now I draw.
Thou marshall'st me the way that I was going;
And such an instrument I was to use.
Mine eyes are made the fools o' the other senses,
Or else worth all the rest; I see thee still,
And on thy blade and dudgeon gouts of blood,
Which was not so before. There's no such thing:
It is the bloody business which informs
Thus to mine eyes. Now o'er the one halfworld
Nature seems dead, and wicked dreams abuse
The curtain'd sleep; witchcraft celebrates
Pale Hecate's offerings, and wither'd murder,
Alarum'd by his sentinel, the wolf,
Whose howl's his watch, thus with his stealthy pace.
With Tarquin's ravishing strides, towards his design
Moves like a ghost. Thou sure and firm-set earth,
Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear
Thy very stones prate of my whereabout,
And take the present horror from the time,
Which now suits with it. Whiles I threat, he lives:
Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives.
I go, and it is done; the bell invites me.
Hear it not, Duncan; for it is a knell
That summons thee to heaven or to hell.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold;
What hath quench'd them hath given me fire.
Hark! Peace!
It was the owl that shriek'd, the fatal bellman,
Which gives the stern'st good-night. He is about it:
The doors are open; and the surfeited grooms
Do mock their charge with snores: I have drugg'd
their possets,
That death and nature do contend about them,
Whether they live or die.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Within Who's there? what, ho!

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Alack, I am afraid they have awaked,
And 'tis not done. The attempt and not the deed
Confounds us. Hark! I laid their daggers ready;
He could not miss 'em. Had he not resembled
My father as he slept, I had done't.
My husband!

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.
Did not you speak?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: When?

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Now.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: As I descended?

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Hark!
Who lies i' the second chamber?

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Donalbain.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: This is a sorry sight.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: There's one did laugh in's sleep, and one cried
'Murder!'
That they did wake each other: I stood and heard them:
But they did say their prayers, and address'd them
Again to sleep.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: There are two lodged together.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: One cried 'God bless us!' and 'Amen' the other;
As they had seen me with these hangman's hands.
Listening their fear, I could not say 'Amen,'
When they did say 'God bless us!'

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Consider it not so deeply.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: But wherefore could not I pronounce 'Amen'?
I had most need of blessing, and 'Amen'
Stuck in my throat.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: These deeds must not be thought
After these ways; so, it will make us mad.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Methought I heard a voice cry 'Sleep no more!
Macbeth does murder sleep', the innocent sleep,
Sleep that knits up the ravell'd sleeve of care,
The death of each day's life, sore labour's bath,
Balm of hurt minds, great nature's second course,
Chief nourisher in life's feast,--

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: What do you mean?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Still it cried 'Sleep no more!' to all the house:
'Glamis hath murder'd sleep, and therefore Cawdor
Shall sleep no more; Macbeth shall sleep no more.'

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Who was it that thus cried? Why, worthy thane,
You do unbend your noble strength, to think
So brainsickly of things. Go get some water,
And wash this filthy witness from your hand.
Why did you bring these daggers from the place?
They must lie there: go carry them; and smear
The sleepy grooms with blood.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: I'll go no more:
I am afraid to think what I have done;
Look on't again I dare not.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Infirm of purpose!
Give me the daggers: the sleeping and the dead
Are but as pictures: 'tis the eye of childhood
That fears a painted devil. If he do bleed,
I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal;
For it must seem their guilt.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Whence is that knocking?
How is't with me, when every noise appals me?
What hands are here? ha! they pluck out mine eyes.
Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood
Clean from my hand? No, this my hand will rather
The multitudinous seas in incarnadine,
Making the green one red.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: My hands are of your colour; but I shame
To wear a heart so white.
I hear a knocking
At the south entry: retire we to our chamber;
A little water clears us of this deed:
How easy is it, then! Your constancy
Hath left you unattended.
Hark! more knocking.
Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us,
And show us to be watchers. Be not lost
So poorly in your thoughts.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: To know my deed, 'twere best not know myself.
Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst!

speech.speaker: Porter
speech.line: Here's a knocking indeed! If a
man were porter of hell-gate, he should have
old turning the key.
Knock,
knock, knock! Who's there, i' the name of
Beelzebub? Here's a farmer, that hanged
himself on the expectation of plenty: come in
time; have napkins enow about you; here
you'll sweat for't.
Knock,
knock! Who's there, in the other devil's
name? Faith, here's an equivocator, that could
swear in both the scales against either scale;
who committed treason enough for God's sake,
yet could not equivocate to heaven: O, come
in, equivocator.
Knock,
knock, knock! Who's there? Faith, here's an
English tailor come hither, for stealing out of
a French hose: come in, tailor; here you may
roast your goose.
Knock,
knock; never at quiet! What are you? But
this place is too cold for hell. I'll devil-porter
it no further: I had thought to have let in
some of all professions that go the primrose
way to the everlasting bonfire.
Anon, anon! I pray you, remember the porter.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed,
That you do lie so late?

speech.speaker: Porter
speech.line: 'Faith sir, we were carousing till the
second cock: and drink, sir, is a great
provoker of three things.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: What three things does drink especially provoke?

speech.speaker: Porter
speech.line: Marry, sir, nose-painting, sleep, and
urine. Lechery, sir, it provokes, and unprovokes;
it provokes the desire, but it takes
away the performance: therefore, much drink
may be said to be an equivocator with lechery:
it makes him, and it mars him; it sets
him on, and it takes him off; it persuades him,
and disheartens him; makes him stand to, and
not stand to; in conclusion, equivocates him
in a sleep, and, giving him the lie, leaves him.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.

speech.speaker: Porter
speech.line: That it did, sir, i' the very throat on
me: but I requited him for his lie; and, I
think, being too strong for him, though he took
up my legs sometime, yet I made a shift to cast
him.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Is thy master stirring?
Our knocking has awaked him; here he comes.

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: Good morrow, noble sir.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Good morrow, both.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Is the king stirring, worthy thane?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Not yet.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: He did command me to call timely on him:
I have almost slipp'd the hour.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: I'll bring you to him.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: I know this is a joyful trouble to you;
But yet 'tis one.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: The labour we delight in physics pain.
This is the door.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: I'll make so bold to call,
For 'tis my limited service.

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: Goes the king hence to-day?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: He does: he did appoint so.

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: The night has been unruly: where we lay,
Our chimneys were blown down; and, as they say,
Lamentings heard i' the air; strange screams of death,
And prophesying with accents terrible
Of dire combustion and confused events
New hatch'd to the woeful time: the obscure bird
Clamour'd the livelong night: some say, the earth
Was feverous and did shake.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: 'Twas a rough night.

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: My young remembrance cannot parallel
A fellow to it.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: O horror, horror, horror! Tongue nor heart
Cannot conceive nor name thee!

speech.speaker: MACBETH
LENNOX
speech.line: What's the matter.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Confusion now hath made his masterpiece!
Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope
The Lord's anointed temple, and stole thence
The life o' the building!

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: What is 't you say? the life?

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: Mean you his majesty?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Approach the chamber, and destroy your sight
With a new Gorgon: do not bid me speak;
See, and then speak yourselves.
Awake, awake!
Ring the alarum-bell. Murder and treason!
Banquo and Donalbain! Malcolm! awake!
Shake off this downy sleep, death's counterfeit,
And look on death itself! up, up, and see
The great doom's image! Malcolm! Banquo!
As from your graves rise up, and walk like sprites,
To countenance this horror! Ring the bell.

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: What's the business,
That such a hideous trumpet calls to parley
The sleepers of the house? speak, speak!

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: O gentle lady,
'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak:
The repetition, in a woman's ear,
Would murder as it fell.
O Banquo, Banquo,
Our royal master 's murder'd!

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Woe, alas!
What, in our house?

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: Too cruel any where.
Dear Duff, I prithee, contradict thyself,
And say it is not so.

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter MACBETH and LENNOX, with ROSS

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Had I but died an hour before this chance,
I had lived a blessed time; for, from this instant,
There 's nothing serious in mortality:
All is but toys: renown and grace is dead;
The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees
Is left this vault to brag of.

speech.speaker: DONALBAIN
speech.line: What is amiss?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: You are, and do not know't:
The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood
Is stopp'd; the very source of it is stopp'd.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Your royal father 's murder'd.

speech.speaker: MALCOLM
speech.line: O, by whom?

speech.speaker: LENNOX
speech.line: Those of his chamber, as it seem'd, had done 't:
Their hands and faces were an badged with blood;
So were their daggers, which unwiped we found
Upon their pillows:
They stared, and were distracted; no man's life
Was to be trusted with them.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: O, yet I do repent me of my fury,
That I did kill them.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Wherefore did you so?

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Who can be wise, amazed, temperate and furious,
Loyal and neutral, in a moment? No man:
The expedition my violent love
Outrun the pauser, reason. Here lay Duncan,
His silver skin laced with his golden blood;
And his gash'd stabs look'd like a breach in nature
For ruin's wasteful entrance: there, the murderers,
Steep'd in the colours of their trade, their daggers
Unmannerly breech'd with gore: who could refrain,
That had a heart to love, and in that heart
Courage to make 's love known?

speech.speaker: LADY MACBETH
speech.line: Help me hence, ho!

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Look to the lady.

speech.speaker: MALCOLM
speech.line: Aside to DONALBAIN Why do we hold our tongues,
That most may claim this argument for ours?

speech.speaker: DONALBAIN
speech.line: Aside to MALCOLM What should be spoken here,
where our fate,
Hid in an auger-hole, may rush, and seize us?
Let 's away;
Our tears are not yet brew'd.

speech.speaker: MALCOLM
speech.line: Aside to DONALBAIN Nor our strong sorrow
Upon the foot of motion.

speech.speaker: BANQUO
speech.line: Look to the lady:
And when we have our naked frailties hid,
That suffer in exposure, let us meet,
And question this most bloody piece of work,
To know it further. Fears and scruples shake us:
In the great hand of God I stand; and thence
Against the undivulged pretence I fight
Of treasonous malice.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: And so do I.

speech.speaker: ALL
speech.line: So all.

speech.speaker: MACBETH
speech.line: Let's briefly put on manly readiness,
And meet i' the hall together.

speech.speaker: ALL
speech.line: Well contented.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt all but Malcolm and Donalbain

speech.speaker: MALCOLM
speech.line: What will you do? Let's not consort with them:
To show an unfelt sorrow is an office
Which the false man does easy. I'll to England.

speech.speaker: DONALBAIN
speech.line: To Ireland, I; our separated fortune
Shall keep us both the safer: where we are,
There's daggers in men's smiles: the near in blood,
The nearer bloody.

speech.speaker: MALCOLM
speech.line: This murderous shaft that's shot
Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way
Is to avoid the aim. Therefore, to horse;
And let us not be dainty of leave-taking,
But shift away: there's warrant in that theft
Which steals itself, when there's no mercy left.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter ROSS and an old Man

speech.speaker: Old Man
speech.line: Threescore and ten I can remember well:
Within the volume of which time I have seen
Hours dreadful and things strange; but this sore night
Hath trifled former knowings.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Ah, good father,
Thou seest, the heavens, as troubled with man's act,
Threaten his bloody stage: by the clock, 'tis day,
And yet dark night strangles the travelling lamp:
Is't night's predominance, or the day's shame,
That darkness does the face of earth entomb,
When living light should kiss it?

speech.speaker: Old Man
speech.line: 'Tis unnatural,
Even like the deed that's done. On Tuesday last,
A falcon, towering in her pride of place,
Was by a mousing owl hawk'd at and kill'd.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: And Duncan's horses--a thing most strange and certain--
Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race,
Turn'd wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out,
Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would make
War with mankind.

speech.speaker: Old Man
speech.line: 'Tis said they eat each other.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: They did so, to the amazement of mine eyes
That look'd upon't. Here comes the good Macduff.
How goes the world, sir, now?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Why, see you not?

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Is't known who did this more than bloody deed?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Those that Macbeth hath slain.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Alas, the day!
What good could they pretend?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: They were suborn'd:
Malcolm and Donalbain, the king's two sons,
Are stol'n away and fled; which puts upon them
Suspicion of the deed.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: 'Gainst nature still!
Thriftless ambition, that wilt ravin up
Thine own life's means! Then 'tis most like
The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: He is already named, and gone to Scone
To be invested.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Where is Duncan's body?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Carried to Colmekill,
The sacred storehouse of his predecessors,
And guardian of their bones.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Will you to Scone?

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: No, cousin, I'll to Fife.

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Well, I will thither.

speech.speaker: MACDUFF
speech.line: Well, may you see things well done there: adieu!
Lest our old robes sit easier than our new!

speech.speaker: ROSS
speech.line: Farewell, father.

speech.speaker: Old Man
speech.line: God's benison go with you; and with those
That would make good of bad, and friends of foes!
